tooltip.title: Weekly new cases
tooltip.body: The weekly new cases number is divided by every 100K people in a location. For instance, if a location has 200K people, we would divide the average weekly new cases by two.

tooltip.title: Infection rate
tooltip.body: This one is a bit complicated. To calculate the infection growth, a mathematical model combines trends in daily new cases from approximately the last 14 days, with estimates for other variables, such as how many days on average occur between infection and transmission.

tooltip.title: Positive test rate
tooltip.body: Positive test rate is the number of positive PCR tests over the last 7 days, divided by the total number of PCR tests over the last 7 days.

tooltip.title: ICU capacity used
tooltip.body: ICU capacity used is the number of staffed ICU beds that are occupied (by both COVID and non-COVID patients), divided by the total number of staffed ICU beds.
For “Shot 1” in a given location, we take the number of people who have received their first shot and divide it by that location’s total population, according to the U.S. Census Bureau.
tooltip.title: Percent vaccinated
Weekly admissions
tooltip.body: To calculate this metric for counties, we use data [from the CDC](https://data.cdc.gov/Public-Health-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Community-Levels-by-County/3nnm-4jni).  To calculate this metric for metros, we aggregate the county data using a population-weighted average. To calculate this metric for states, we use data [from the HHS](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the number of admissions over the last week and then normalize that by the state’s population.

tooltip.title: Patients w/ COVID
tooltip.body: To calculate this metric for counties, we use data [from the CDC](https://data.cdc.gov/Public-Health-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Community-Levels-by-County/3nnm-4jni) which is based on hospitals in the health service area.  To calculate this metric for metros, we aggregate the county data using a population-weighted average. To calculate this metric for states, we use data [from the HHS](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the number of patients with confirmed COVID divided by the number of staffed inpatient beds.

tooltip.title: Daily new cases
tooltip.body: Our daily new cases number is a seven-day average divided by every 100K people in a location. For instance, if a location has 200K people, we would divide the average daily new cases by two.
